setting.label: Site URL
setting.description: The URL to this application, as seen by users. The value is used in email macros and other user facing communications. Example: http://www.example.com/password. The site URL must use a valid fully qualified hostname. Do not use a network address.

setting.label: Enable Version Checking
setting.description: Allow periodically checks for new versions. If a new version is detected, an item will be shown on the health check.

setting.label: Enable Anonymous Statistics Publishing
setting.description:
If true, the statistics of this application are periodically published statics to the project website. The published statistics are:
  • Instance Name
  • Version/Build Information
  • Cumulative Statistics
  • Which settings are non default (but not the actual setting values
Leaving this feature enabled helps developers know which features are used by administrators.

setting.label: Site Description
setting.description: If Anonymous statistics publishing is enabled, this optional site description is published along with the otherwise anonymous statistics. This can be an organization name, or other similar value.

setting.label: Forward URL
setting.description:
After completing any activity which does not require a logout, the user will be forwarded to this url.

This setting can always be overridden for any given user session by adding a forwardURL parameter to any HTTP request. If blank, the user will be forward to the application menu.

setting.label: Logout URL
setting.description:
URL to redirect user to upon logout. If the site is being accessed through a web authentication gateway, the Logout URL should be set to the gateway's Logout URL. If you are using a gateway and do not include the proper logout URL here, then users will almost certainly get authentication errors, intruder lockouts and other problems. If things are working properly then the user should see the gateway logout screen when logging out.

The Logout URL can be set to any desired relative or absolute URL. At the time the user's browser requests this url, the local session will have already been invalidated.

This setting can always be overridden for any given user session by adding a logoutURL parameter to any HTTP request during the session.

setting.label: Home URL
setting.description: The URL to redirect user to upon clicking the home button. If blank, the home button will return the user to the application context URL.

setting.label: Instance Name
setting.description: Name of this application instance. If blank a persistent, randomly generated value will be used. Recommended value is blank.

setting.label: Idle Timeout Seconds
setting.description: Number of seconds after which an authenticated session becomes unauthenticated.

setting.label: Hide Configuration Health Warnings
setting.description: Hide health warnings about configuration issues from the health status monitors.

setting.label: App Property Overides
setting.description: Override application properties. Do not use unless directed to by a support expert.

setting.label: Locales (Languages) and Flags
setting.description: List of locales available. The code is in two parts separated by two colons. The first part is the browser locale code, the second field is the iso country code used for the flag value.

setting.label: Locale Cookie Age
setting.description: Duration of time to remember a user's locale preferences. Anytime a browser's default locale setting is overridden, a cookie will be stored in the browser remembering that setting for the duration of this setting.

setting.label: Interface Theme
setting.description: Change the look and feel by selecting a theme. The included themes are provided to mainly to inspiration to those wishing to make customizations. If Embedded is selected, the settings User Interface -> Embedded CSS Stylesheet and User Interface -> Embedded Mobile CSS Stylesheet will be used to manage the custom CSS tags. If Custom is selected, the settings User Interface -> Custom CSS Location and Custom Mobile CSS Location.

setting.label: Show Auto Generate Randoms
setting.description: If set to true, a link will be displayed to users during the change password process to display a list of auto-generated sample passwords that are allowed by the configured password policies. The user will have the option to select and use one of the values in the list. If this option feature is enabled the user is not forced to choose a password from the list.

setting.label: Show Strength Meter
setting.description: If true, the user will see the password strength meter on the change password screen.

setting.label: Enable Showing Masked Fields
setting.description: Where available, allow the user to toggle the show/hide masked (hidden) data input fields. This setting applies to all HTML masked password fields, regardless of the actual data type.

setting.label: Mask Password Fields
setting.description: Mask sensitive input fields with standard "password" masking. If set to false, sensitive fields will be shown as normal text input fields.

setting.label: Mask Response Fields
setting.description: Mask challenge/response answer input fields with standard "password" masking. If set to false, response fields will be shown as normal text input fields. This setting applies to both setup responses and forgotten password response entry screens.

setting.label: Show Cancel Button
setting.description: Where appropriate, show a "Cancel" button to user. Pressing the cancel button will send the user to the forwardURL (or logoutURL if the password has been modified). The cancel button will show on the change password screen only if the password is not expired. The Cancel button will only show up if the browser has javaScript enabled.

setting.label: Show Clear Button
setting.description: Where appropriate, show a "Clear" button to user. Pressing the clear button will clear the form field values to their original values.

setting.label: Show Success Pages
setting.description: When an activity completes successfully, Normally a "success" page is shown to the user informing the user the action is completed. This page can be bypassed by changing this setting to false.

setting.label: Enable Account Information
setting.description: Show User Account Information menu on main menu.

setting.label: Show Password Event History
setting.description: Show logged in users their password event history. The password event history will appear as a tab on the account information page.

setting.label: Show Login Page Options
setting.description: If true, the login page will display the "Forgotten Password" and other options (if those components are enabled).

setting.label: Show Logout Button
setting.description: When authenticated, show a logout button in header and/or other menus as appropriate.

setting.label: Show Home Button
setting.description: When authenticated, show a "home" button in header and/or other menus as appropriate.

setting.label: Show Idle Timeout Counter
setting.description: Show the user's remaining idle time, and when that time reaches zero, redirect the user to the logout page.

setting.label: Custom CSS Stylesheet Location
setting.description: URL Location (and name) of the custom style.css resource. The setting User Interface -> Theme must be set to Custom for this setting to be useful. If this URL is relative, it will be appended to the context path.

setting.label: Custom Mobile CSS Stylesheet Location
setting.description: URL Location (and name) of the custom mobileStyle.css resource. The setting User Interface -> Theme must be set to Custom for this setting to be useful. If this URL is relative, it will be appended to the context path.

setting.label: Embedded CSS Stylesheet
setting.description: Contents of the custom CSS Stylesheet. The setting User Interface -> Theme must be set to Embed for this setting to be useful. The contents of this setting will be served from the "virtual" url of /public/resources/themes/embed/style.css.

setting.label: Embedded Mobile CSS Stylesheet
setting.description: Contents of the custom mobile CSS Stylesheet. The setting User Interface -> Theme must be set to Embed for this setting to be useful. The contents of this setting will be served from the "virtual" url of /public/resources/themes/embed/mobileStyle.css.

setting.label: Embedded JavaScript
setting.description: Contents of this setting will be injected into all pages inside a <script></script> html tag near the bottom of the page.

setting.label: Custom Resource Bundle
setting.description:
This setting allows a custom ZIP file containing static HTTP resources to be served by the application from the HTTP path /public/resources/ to be added to the configuration.

The maximum zip file size is 10MB. Files included should be types of html, text, images, etc. No server side processing will be performed when serving these files.

setting.label: Change Password Permission
setting.description: Permissions used to detect if a user is a permitted to change password.

setting.label: Logout After Password Change
setting.description:
Force user to logout (and be sent to logoutURL) after a password change.

In most cases, this should be left on (default), especially if using some type of single sign on service.

setting.label: Change Password Required Values Form
setting.description: Values required to be entered prior to password change.

setting.label: Require Current Password during change
setting.description: If true, the user's current password will be required on the change password page for most change password scenarios. In most cases this is not required because the user just authenticated prior to the seeing the change password page. The major exception is when using SSO, in that case you will probably what to set "Only when not expired" so that the current password must be supplied when the user attempts a password change during a session, but not when forced to change immediately upon authentication.

setting.label: Password Change Agreement Message
setting.description:
Message to display to user before being allowed to change password. If blank, the change password agreement page will not be displayed to the user. This message may include HTML tags.

This setting may use Macros. See the "View" menu "Show Macro Help" for more information about Macros.

setting.label: Password Change Completion Message
setting.description:
Message to display to user when password change is completed. If blank, the change password completion page will not be displayed to the user. This message may include HTML tags.

This setting may use Macros. See the "View" menu "Show Macro Help" for more information about Macros.

setting.label: Password Guide Text
setting.description:
Text (with HTML tags/formatting) to show user on password guide page. This will show up as a "password guide" link and pop-up dialog. Leave blank to not show the password guide link.

This setting may use Macros. See the "View" menu "Show Macro Help" for more information about Macros.

setting.label: Password Sync Enable Replication Checking
setting.description: Check for the password to be updated on all configured replicas (for a user's LDAP Profile). When enabled, replica sync checking will poll all of the configured replicas on the user's LDAP Profile to determine if the password change time has been updated. The particular method to determine the last password change time varies per LDAP vendor type.

options.option: DISABLED - Do not perform replica sync checking
ENABLED - Enabled, but do not display individual progress to user
ENABLED and Display - Enable replica sync checking and display progress to user

setting.label: Password Change Minimum Wait Time
setting.description:
During a password change, a delay of this amount will be waited for before forwarding the user. This gives any background synchronization processes time to execute before the user executes the next operation.

Value is specified in seconds.

setting.label: Password Change Maximum Wait Time
setting.description:
During a password change, the system will wait for the password to be synchronized to all configured LDAP servers. In cases where the synchronization may take an extraordinary amount of time, this setting will prevent the page from timing out.

Value is specified in seconds.

setting.label: Password Pre-Expire Time
setting.description:
Number of seconds before a user's password expires in which to force the user to change their password. If the user's password will expire within this time frame, the system will behave as if the user's password has already expired.

Setting this value to a day or so will prevent most cases of a user's password expiring while they are logged in. The recommend setting for this value is 86400 (1 day).

setting.label: Password ExpireWarn Time
setting.description:
Number of seconds before a user's password expires in which to warn the user to change their password. If the user's password will expire within this time frame, the system will warn the user during a CommandServlet checkExpire or checkAll operation.

If this time is zero or less than the expirePreTime, this feature will be disabled. The recommended setting for this value is 432000 (5 days).

setting.label: Check Expire During Authentication
setting.description: When the user is authenticated, should there be a check to see if the user's password is expired (or about to expire based on the expirePreTime). If this is set to true, and the user's password is expired, they will be forced to the expire password page.

setting.label: Seedlist File
setting.description:
When passwords are randomly generated, the system can generate "friendly" random password suggestions to users. It does this by using a "seed" word or words, and then modifying that word randomly until it is sufficiently complex and meets the configured rules computed for the user.

Setting this to blank will result in suggested passwords being completely randomized.

setting.label: Post Password Change Actions
setting.description: Actions to take when after a user change password event occurs. These actions will be invoked just after writing the password. Macros can be used within the action and will be expanded based on the logged in user.

setting.label: LDAP Directory Profiles
setting.description:
List of LDAP profiles. Each ldap profile should define a unique LDAP data environment. Depending on the directory type and configuration, this could mean a unique domain, forest, tree or possibly server. Each profile can have multiple redundant servers defined, however those servers should share the same data.

Be careful when renaming or removing values in this list, if a profile name is removed or renamed the associated settings will be removed as well.

During authentication, each profile will be searched in the order listed here.

Profile names have the following requirements:

  • Start with a letter (a-Z)
  • Contain only letters, numbers and hyphens
  • Length between 2 and 15 characters

setting.label: LDAP URLs
setting.description:
List of ldap servers in URL format. Each of these these servers will be used in a fail-over configuration. The servers are used in order of appearance in this list. If the first server is unavailable the next available server in the list will be used. The first server will periodically be checked to see if it has become available.
  • For secure SSL, use the "ldaps://servername:636" format
  • For plain-text servers, use "ldap://serverame:389" format (not recommended)

When using secure connections, the Java virtual machine must trust the directory server, either because you have manually added the public key certificate from the tree to the Java keystore or the certificate is imported into the setting LDAP Server Certificates.

  • Do not use a non-secure connection for anything but the most basic testing purposes (Many LDAP servers will reject password operations on non-secure connections)
  • Do not use a load-balancing device for LDAP high availability, instead use the built in LDAP server fail-over functionality
  • Do not use a DNS round-robin address
  • Avoid using the network address, use the proper fully-qualified domain name address for the server

setting.label: LDAP Certificates
setting.description: LDAP Server Certificates. These certificates have are stored in the configuration file and used to validate the identity of your LDAP server.

setting.label: LDAP Proxy User
setting.description:
LDAP Proxy User used to access the ldap directory. This user must have rights to browse users, and manage password attributes on the user object.

This value should be in LDAP distinguished name format, even if your ldap directory accepts other types of values for the bind DN. An example of this format is cn=admin,o=example or cn=administrator,cn=users,dc=subdomain,dc=domain,dc=net.

Generally, the proxy user needs read/browse object rights to all user objects it will manage, as well as create object rights in the new user container (if enabled).

setting.label: LDAP Proxy Password
setting.description: The corresponding password of LDAP Proxy User user.

setting.label: LDAP Contextless Login Roots
setting.description: Base context to search for usernames during authentication and other operations. Each context will be searched in order until a single match is found. If multiple matches are found in a single context, a match will be considered not found. Because each search is executed serially, avoid large numbers of contexts to improve search performance.

setting.label: User Selectable Login Contexts
setting.description:
This optional setting, if configured, will add another field to the form-based login screen and other user search screens. The field will allow the user to select a specific context. This is for situations where the ldap directory that does not have unique usernames throughout the entire directory.

Values can further be set with both a display value and a context, separated by three colons.

For example:

ou=sf,ou=ca,o=example:::San Francisco
ou=lon,ou=uk,o=example:::London
ou=nyc,ou=ny,o=example:::New York

setting.label: LDAP Test User
setting.description:
The LDAP test user is used to test functionality and access to the ldap directory. This user should be configured similar to a normal user account with normal access privileges. This account will periodically be used to perform a health check, including changing the password of the account.

Using a test user account will greatly increase the ability to detect and alert configuration and health issues.

The following functionality (if enabled) will be tested using the test user account.
  • Authentication
  • Password policy reading
  • Set password
  • Set challenge/responses
  • Load challenge/responses

setting.label: Administrator Permission
setting.description: Permissions used to determine if a user will be granted administrator rights.

setting.label: Username Search Filter
setting.description: Used to for contextless login and other functions to find users in ldap using usernames. The value %USERNAME% is replaced with the actual username value.

setting.label: Auto Add Object Classes
setting.description: Object classes to automatically add to users who authenticate to the password servlet. Typically this is an auxillary ldap class that contains attributes used by to store password self service data.

setting.label: Last Password Update Attribute
setting.description: This attribute is used to mark when the password is updated, and is used during replication checks, and other processes.

setting.label: User Group Attribute
setting.description: Attribute on user entry that references group entries. The value of this attribute in the directory must be a LDAP DN.

setting.label: User Group Entry Label
setting.description: Display value for group entries. Can include LDAP macros; LDAP macros will resolve to the group entry object.

setting.label: LDAP GUID Attribute
setting.description: This attribute is used to identity and reference unique users in the LDAP directory. If set to the default value of VENDORGUID, the system will attempt to read the vendor specific ldap GUID. Alternatively, you can set any string readable attribute as the GUID as long as the directory can be trusted to enforce the uniqueness. Lastly, you can use a custom attribute, and configure the "Auto Add GUID Value" option to true. The application defined schema includes the attribute pwmGUID for this usage.

setting.label: LDAP Naming Attribute
setting.description: Attribute name used as the naming attribute on ldap user entries. This value is also the first part of the distinguished name of a user. This name is constant depending on directory vendor type, even if a different attribute is used for the login search filter. Typically the naming attribute is cn or uid.

setting.label: LDAP Idle Timeout
setting.description: Amount of seconds the LDAP connection for a given session can remain idle before closing. If zero, then an ldap connection will be maintained throughout the lifetime of the http session.

setting.label: Auto Add GUID Value
setting.description: If true, A unique GUID value will be created and assigned for any user attempting to authenticate that does not have a value. The value will be written to the attribute named in the LDAP GUID Attribute setting.

setting.label: LDAP Duplicate Mode
setting.description: Control how the application will handle the situation when multiple user matches are found for a search, such as during authentication.

options.option: Match first user - Use first user discovered in any context or profile, ignore any duplicates
Match first ldap profile - Use the first user discovered in the first profile that has only a single match
No duplicates Permitted - Fail whenever duplicate users are found in any context or profile

setting.label: User Selectable LDAP Context/Profile
setting.description: Control if the ldap context or profile is shown to the user as an option during user identification (login, forgotten password, etc).

options.option: Show the ldap profile and ldap contexts

setting.label: Ignore Unreachable LDAP Profiles
setting.description: When multiple LDAP profiles exist, ignore unreachable profiles. A Directory Unavailable error will only be shown during a user search when there is only a single LDAP Profile configured or all LDAP Profiles are unreachable.

setting.label: LDAP Profile Display Name
setting.description: Display name used for this LDAP Profile.

setting.label: LDAP Profile Enabled
setting.description: Indicate if this ldap profile should be in use. For maintenance reasons, it may be helpful to remove an LDAP Profile from use instead of deleting the profile's configuration entirely.

setting.label: Attribute to use for Username
setting.description: If blank, the LDAP Naming Attribute will be used. This option allows fields that display or store the Username or UserID of a user to show something other then the LDAP Naming Attribute if appropriate. It is desirable that this value be unique for this system.

setting.label: Follow LDAP Referrals
setting.description: Follow LDAP Referrals
setting.regex: Follow LDAP Referrals. Not typically required.

setting.label: User Object Class
setting.description: Object class(es) of user entries in your LDAP directory.

setting.label: SMTP Email Server Address
setting.description: Any emails generated by will be sent via this server. Removing this setting will prevent sending any email at all. Be sure the server listed here allows relaying. For best results, use a local smtp server.

setting.label: SMTP Email Server Port
setting.description: Network port number for SMTP server

setting.label: Default From Address
setting.description: Default From Address

setting.label: SMTP Email Server Username
setting.description: Any emails generated will be sent by logging into server with this user. A blank value will here will send SMTP messages without authentication.

setting.label: SMTP Email Server Password
setting.description: Any emails generated will be sent by logging into server with this password. A blank value will here will send SMTP messages without authentication.

setting.label: User Email Attribute
setting.description: User LDAP attribute containing the user's email address.

setting.label: Maximum Email Queue Age
setting.description: Maximum age (in seconds) an email can wait in the send queue. If an email is in the send queue longer than this time, it will be discarded. Emails only persist in the send queue if there is an IO or network error to the smtp server while sending the email.

setting.label: SMTP Email Advanced Settings
setting.description: Name/Value settings to control the behavior of the mail agent.Available settings are defined as part of the JavaMail API. The settings must be in "name=value" format, where name is the key value of a valid JavaMail API setting.

setting.label: SMS Destintion Address LDAP Attribute
setting.description: User LDAP attribute containing the user's mobile phone number for SMS.

setting.label: Maximum SMS Queue Age
setting.description: Maximum age (in seconds) an sms can wait in the local send queue. If an sms is in the send queue longer than this time, it will be discarded. SMS messages only persist in the send queue if there is an IO or network error to the sms gateway server while sending the message.

setting.label: SMS Gateway
setting.description: URL for the SMS gateway

setting.label: SMS Gateway User
setting.description: User name for the SMS gateway

setting.label: SMS Gateway Password
setting.description: User password for the SMS gateway

setting.label: HTTP(S) Method
setting.description: HTTP(S) protocol method to be used for sending SMS messages.

setting.label: SMS Gateway Authentication Method
setting.description: Method to be used for authentication on the SMS gateway.

options.option: Request - Authentication will be part of the request

setting.label: SMS Request Data
setting.description:
The data to be submitted in order to send an SMS message. You can usecertain codes that will be replaced:
  • %USER%: authentication user name
  • %PASS%: authentication password
  • %SENDERID%: sender identification
  • %TO%: recipient SMS number
  • %REQUESTID%: randomly generated request identifier
  • %MESSAGE%: the message to be sent

setting.label: SMS Data Content Type
setting.description:
Content Type for POST data. This is the mime type for the content. This only applies if the HTTP(S) Method is POST. Common values are:
  • application/x-www-form-urlencoded: HTTP form data
  • text/plain: Plain ASCII data
  • text/xml: XML document
Optionally, a character set can be appended. Eg.:
  • application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8: HTTP form data in UTF-8 encoding

setting.label: SMS Data Content Encoding
setting.description: Data for fields in the SMS data may need encoding or escaping.

options.option: CSV - Escape for comma separated values
Javascript - recommended for JSON formatted documents
SQL - turn single-quotes (') into double single-quotes ('')
URL - recommended for GET requests and POST with form data (default)
XML - for XML and/or SOAP services

setting.label: SMS Gateway HTTP Request Headers
setting.description: Additional HTTP request headers for the SMS request, for example SOAPAction for SOAP messages.

setting.label: Maximum SMS Text Length
setting.description: Maximum length for SMS text. Some services allow texts longer than one message (generally 140 bytes). If the text is longer than the configured maximum, multiple requests will be made.

setting.label: Response Regular Expressions
setting.description: Regular expressions that can be used to determine whether the SMS has been sent successfully. If the response matches any of the expressions, the transmission is considered succesful. If no expressions are entered, all transmissions are assumed successful. NOTE: the string must match an entire line. Use <tt>.*</tt> to match anything after the required texts.

setting.label: SMS Sender ID
setting.description: Alphanumerical sender identification. If blank, the provider will most likely use a default or anonymous sender identification. In most cases the sender ID must be validated by the SMS provider. Please contact your provider for values that can be used as a valid sender identification.

setting.label: SMS Phone Number Format
setting.description: The format that should be used for the mobile phone number.

options.option: Plain - country code (e.g. 1 for USA) plus subscriber number (e.g. 12312345): 112312345
Plus - Same as plain, but with a plus sign as a prefix: +112312345
Zeros - Same as plain, but prefixed with a double zero: 00112312345

setting.label: Default SMS Country Code
setting.description: Default country code for SMS phone numbers, see http://countrycode.org/ for a list of country codes. Set to 0 to disable.

setting.label: Request ID Characters
setting.description: Available characters SMS request ID.

setting.label: Request ID Length
setting.description: Length of the SMS request ID.

setting.label: Forgotten Password SMS Text
setting.description: Message text of SMS sent during forgotten password token process.

setting.label: Forgotten Password New Password SMS Text
setting.description: Message text of SMS with new password sent during forgotten password process.

setting.label: New User Verification SMS Text
setting.description: Text of SMS sent during new user verification process.

setting.label: Helpdesk Verification SMS Text
setting.description: Message text of SMS sent during helpdesk token verification process.

setting.label: Forgotten Username SMS Text

setting.label: Use URL Shortener
setting.description: Enable this option to use a url shortener service like tinyurl.com, bit.ly and goo.gl. This will enable searching the SMS text for http and https urls and replace them with a shortened version. The service to be used can be configured under the Miscellaneous options. Be sure to check View|Advanced.

setting.label: Successful HTTP Result Codes
setting.description: HTTP Result codes that will be considered successful send attempts.

setting.label: Password Policy Profiles
setting.description:
List of Password Policy Profiles. When multiple password policy profiles are configured, all profiles except for the default are evaluated in order to check if the Password Policy Profile Query Match during user authentication matches the user. If no profiles match, then the Default profile will be used.

Profile names have the following requirements:

  • Start with a letter (a-Z)
  • Contain only letters, numbers and hyphens
  • Length between 2 and 15 characters

setting.label: Password Policy Profile Match
setting.description: Settings here are used to determine if this password policy applies to a given user. During login, if a previous policy has not yet been assigned to the user, the matches here are considered and if positive, the user will then be assigned this policy.

setting.label: Password Policy Source
setting.description:
This setting determines where password policy settings should be read from. If LDAP is selected, an attempt to read the policy out of the ldap directory will be made, and many of the following settings could be ignored. If Local Config is selected, the policy settings on this page are used, and any policy settings in the LDAP directory are ignored. If Merge is selected, both policies are read, and where there is any conflict, The application will chose the most restrictive value of the policy.

The capability to read policy from LDAP is only available with some LDAP implementations.

Additionally, the password policy used is only the "local" policy used by this application. Upon a password set operation, the ldap directory will typically enforce whatever policies are configured in the directory itself.

setting.label: Minimum Length
setting.description: Minimum length of password. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Length
setting.description: Maximum length of password. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Repeat
setting.description: Maximum times any character may be repeated throughout the password. Case is ignored for this check. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Sequential Repeat
setting.description: Maximum times any character may be sequentially repeated throughout the password.Case is ignored for this check. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Allow Numeric Characters
setting.description: Allow numeric characters in password.

setting.label: Allow First Character Numeric
setting.description: Allow the first character of the password to be numeric. Applies only if numeric characters are allowed.

setting.label: Allow Last Character Numeric
setting.description: Allow the last character of the password to be numeric. Applies only if numeric characters are allowed.

setting.label: Maximum Numeric
setting.description: Maximum amount of numeric characters required (if numeric allowed). A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Numeric
setting.description: Minimum amount of numeric characters required (if numeric allowed). A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Allow Special Characters
setting.description: Allow special (non alpha-numeric) characters in password.

setting.label: Allow First Character Special
setting.description: Allow the first character of the password to be special. Applies only if special characters are allowed.

setting.label: Allow Last Character Special
setting.description: Allow the last character of the password to be special. Applies only if special characters are allowed.

setting.label: Maximum Special
setting.description: Maximum amount of special characters required (if special allowed). A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Special
setting.description: Minimum amount of special characters required (if special allowed). A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Alphabetic
setting.description: Maximum amount of alphabetic characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Alphabetic
setting.description: Minimum amount of alphabetic characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Non-Alphabetic
setting.description: Maximum amount of non-alphabetic characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Non-Alphabetic
setting.description: Minimum amount of non-alphabetic characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Uppercase
setting.description: Maximum amount of uppercase characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Uppercase
setting.description: Minimum amount of uppercase characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Lowercase
setting.description: Maximum amount of lowercase characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Lowercase
setting.description: Minimum amount of lowercase characters required. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Unique Characters
setting.description: Minimum amount of unique characters allowed. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Characters From Previous Password
setting.description: Maximum amount of characters from the previous password allowed in the new password. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Minimum Lifetime
setting.description: Minimum amount of time that must pass between password changes. Value is in seconds. A value of zero disables this check.

setting.label: Password is Case Sensitive
setting.description: Controls if the password is case sensitive. In most cases, this can be read from the directory, but in some cases this value is not able to correctly read, so you may override it here.

setting.label: Enable Wordlist
setting.description: Check the password against the configured Wordlist.

setting.label: Active Directory Password Complexity
setting.description:
Enforce Microsoft Active Directory 2003 style password complexity rules:
  • Not contain the user's account name or parts of the user's full name that exceed two consecutive characters
  • Be at least six characters in length
  • Contain characters from three of the following four categories:
    • English uppercase characters (A through Z)
    • English lowercase characters (a through z)
    • Base 10 digits (0 through 9)
    • Non-alphabetic characters (for example, !, $, #, %)

options.option: None - Do not enforce AD Complexity Rules

setting.label: Active Directory Password Complexity Maximum Violations
setting.description: Number of Active Directory Password Complexity

setting.label: Required Regular Expression Matches
setting.description: A Regular Expression pattern the password must match in order to be allowed. Multiple patterns can be listed. A pattern must match the entire password to be applied. A partial match is ignored.

setting.label: Disallowed Regular Expression Matches
setting.description: A Regular Expression pattern the password must not match in order to be allowed. Multiple patterns can be listed. A pattern must match the entire password to be applied. A partial match is ignored.

setting.label: Disallowed Values
setting.description: A case insensitive list of values not allowed to be used as passwords.

setting.label: Disallowed Attributes
setting.description: A list of attributes not allowed to be used as passwords. For a given user, the values will be read and will not be permitted to be used as part of the password value. This check is case insensitive.

setting.label: Enable Shared History
setting.description: Enable a global shared password history for all users. If enabled, all users will share a common password history. This helps prevent common organizational words from being used as passwords by users. Passwords are stored as a salted and encrypted hash in the LocalDB.

setting.label: Shared History Age
setting.description: The maximum age of the shared history storage. Value is specified in seconds. Default is 28 days.

setting.label: Minimum Password Strength
setting.description: Password strengths are judged on a strength on a scale of 0 to 100 irrespective of other password policy settings. This setting requires that the user have a password that meets the minimum strength level specified here, regardless of other password policy rules. 45 or better is considered "good" while 70 or better is considered "strong". A value of 0 disables this check.

setting.label: Maximum Consecutive Characters
setting.description: Maximum amount of characters in a sequence such as 0123456789 or abcdefghijk. More specifically character sequence is defined by unicode character order of each character after the entire value is converted to lowercase. A value of 0 disables this check.

setting.label: Password Change Message
setting.description: Message to be displayed to user during password changes. May include HTML markup. This setting may be overwritten by a change password message read as part of an ldap password policy.

setting.label: Password Rule Text
setting.description: Rules to display to user. By default this is blank, and appropriate rule text will be auto-generated to show to the user. However if this setting is configured, the text in this setting will replace the automatically generated rule text. HTML tags are permitted.

setting.label: Disallow Current Password
setting.description: Prohibit current password from being used as new password. Note that this can only be enforced if the login method permits the user's password to be known.

setting.label: Wordlist File
setting.description:
Specify a word list for dictionary checking to prevent users from using commonly used words as passwords. Using wordists is an important part of password security. Wordlists are used by intruders to guess common passwords. The default wordlist included contains commonly used English passwords. More comprehensive wordlists are available.

The first time a startup occurs with a new wordlist setting, it will take some time to compile the wordlist into a database. See the status screen/logs for progress information. The wordlist file format is one or more text files containing a single word per line, enclosed in a ZIP file. The String !#comment: at the beginning of a line indicates a comment. If a full path is not specified, the applications WEB-INF directory is assumed.

setting.label: Wordlist Case Sensitivity
setting.description: If true, the wordlist will be treated as case sensitive for all matches. Changing this value will cause the wordlist to be recompiled.

setting.label: Wordlist Word Size Check
setting.description: Minimum number of characters in the password that are checked against the wordlist dictionary. For example, if the password to be checked is "wordlist" and this setting is set to 6, then the combinations "wordli", "wordlis", "wordlist", "ordlis", "ordlist" and "rdlist" would all be checked against the configured dictionary. If any of these values are equal to any word in the wordlist dictionary, then the password is considered to match the wordlist and will be rejected. If this value is set to zero or the password to check is smaller then the value specified here, then the entire password is checked against the wordlist but not any smaller parts of it.

setting.label: Security Key
setting.description:
A Security Key used for cryptographic functions such as the token verification. A value is required if tokens are enabled for any of modules and a token storage method has been configured. This value is used similar to how the private key in a cryptographic security certificate is used.

If configured, this value must be at least 32 characters in length. The longer and more random this value, the more secure its use will be. If multiple instances are in use, each instance should be configured with the same value.

Upon initial setup, a random security key is assigned to this value, it can be changed at any time, however any outstanding tokens or other material generated by an old security key will become invalid.

setting.label: Intruder User Reset Time
setting.description:
This setting defines the time period after which a bad attempt will be cleared from the lockout table. The user lockout table is marked for a user anytime a user has a failed attempt to authenticate, recover a password, or activate a user account.

Value is in number of seconds. A value of zero disables the user lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder User Maximum Attempts
setting.description: The maximum number of attempts a user may make before a lockout occurs. Once this value is exceeded, the user will not be able to perform any activities until the reset time interval has passed. A value of zero disables the user lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder User Check Time
setting.description: The maximum time period between each intruder attempt. When this time period is exceeded, the intruder attempt count will be reset to zero.

setting.label: Intruder Attribute Reset Time
setting.description:
This setting defines the time period after which a bad attempt will be cleared from the lockout table. The attribute lockout table is marked for a user anytime a non-authenticated user has enter a form field.

Value is in number of seconds. A value of zero disables the attribute lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Attribute Maximum Attempts
setting.description: The maximum number of attempts a user may make before a lockout occurs. Once this value is exceeded, the user will not be able to perform any activities until the reset time interval has passed. A value of zero disables the user lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Attribute Check Time
setting.description: The maximum time period between each intruder attempt. When this time period is exceeded, the intruder attempt count will be reset to zero.

setting.label: Intruder Token Destination Reset Time
setting.description:
This setting defines the time period after which a bad attempt will be cleared from the lockout table. The attribute lockout table is marked for a user anytime a token is sent, and it is cleared when a token is consumed.

Value is in number of seconds. A value of zero disables the attribute lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Token Destination Attempts
setting.description: The maximum number of attempts a user may make before a lockout occurs. Once this value is exceeded, the user will not be able to perform any activities until the reset time interval has passed. A value of zero disables the user lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Token Destination Check Time
setting.description: The maximum time period between each intruder attempt. When this time period is exceeded, the intruder attempt count will be reset to zero.

setting.label: Intruder Address Reset Time
setting.description:
This setting defines the time period after which a bad attempt will be cleared from the lockout table. The address lockout table is marked for any source ip address anytime any user has a failed attempt to authenticate, recover a password, or activate a user account from that address.

Depending on how the application is deployed it may not be able to correctly identify the IP address of the user.

Value is in number of seconds. A value of zero disables the address lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Address Maximum Attempts
setting.description: The maximum number of attempts any user may make within a particular address. Once this value is exceeded, no user from that address will be able to perform any activities until the reset time interval has passed. A value of zero disables the address lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Address Check Time
setting.description: The maximum time period between each intruder attempt. When this time period is exceeded, the intruder attempt count will be reset to zero. A value of zero disables the address lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Address Check Time
setting.description: The maximum time period between each intruder attempt. When this time period is exceeded, the intruder attempt count will be reset to zero. A value of zero disables the address lockout functionality.

setting.label: Intruder Detection Enabled
setting.description: Enable the application level intruder detection system. Your LDAP directory intruder detection settings will function independently of this setting.

setting.label: Intruder Record Storage Location
setting.description: Data store used for Intruder Records. If Database is used, all application instances will share a common view of intruder status. If LocalDB is used, each instance has it's own intruder state. LocalDB is likely to have less performance overhead and having a consistent intruder state across all application instances may not be important. Auto Configure will use a database if configured, if not the LocalDB will be used.

setting.label: Maximum Intruder Attempts Per Session
setting.description: The maximum amount of intruder attempts per session. When this limit is exceeded, the session will be "locked", and no other requests using that session will succeed. A value of zero disables the session lockout functionality.

setting.label: Enable Bad Password Simulation
setting.description: This feature will enable Bad Password simulation activity when a forgotten password field is entered. When an identified user attempts to recover a forgotten password but uses incorrect data, the application will attempt to authenticate to the directory using a known bad password value. This is done to allow the ldap directory to trigger it's own defense mechanisms against intruders.

setting.label: reCAPTCHA Public Key
setting.description: Public reCAPTCHA key. If blank no captcha verification will be performed.

setting.label: reCAPTCHA Private Key
setting.description: Private reCAPTCHA key. If blank no captcha verification will be performed.

setting.label: CAPTCHA Protected Pages
setting.description: Pages protected by CAPTCHA.

setting.label: Captcha Skip Parameter Value
setting.description:
Allows for skipping the captcha request if a known parameter is passed as a request parameter with a key of "skipCaptcha". This is useful for "internal" clients / links where the captcha is unneccessary.

For example, if the value is 'okay', a request to:

/public/ForgottenPassword?skipCaptcha=okay

would cause captcha to be bypassed.

setting.label: Captcha Skip Cookie
setting.description:
Allows for skipping the captcha request if a known browser cookie value is held by the browser the cookie is stored in a cookie named 'captcha-key'. If the value is correct,then the captcha check is skipped. The cookie value is stored in the browser after a successful captcha check.

If blank, then no cookie will be read/stored. If set to 'INSTANCEID', then the instanceID is used. If set to any other value, then the literal value will be used.

setting.label: Enable Back Button Detection
setting.description: Enable detection of the use of back button or other browser navigation irregularities. Enabling this option prevents duplicate HTTP form submissions but can sometimes have side effects.

setting.label: Enable Form Nonce
setting.description: Require a nonce (or unique key) for each form to prevent certain types of cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

setting.label: Session Verification
setting.description:
If enabled, browser sessions will be verified using an HTTP redirect and verification code. This verification proves that the browser can correctly establish a session with the server. Verification proves the browser either supports cookies or URL sessions (if enabled) and the communication channel between browser and application server is 'sticky' when their are multiple server instances. Additionally it helps prevent some types of XSS attacks.

The pre-load browser cache will show a "please wait" screen to the user during the verification. This has the added benefit that many of the HTTP resources (javascript, css, images, etc) will be "pre-cached" by the browser before any actual pages are loaded.

setting.label: Disallowed HTTP Inputs
setting.description: Disallowed values. If any input values (on any http parameter) matches these patterns, the matching portion will be stripped from the input.

setting.label: Require HTTPS
setting.description: Require HTTPS (instead of cleartext HTTP) traffic to the application server. While non-secure connections are useful during testing, production servers should always have this setting set to true.

setting.label: Force Basic Authentication
setting.description: If false, then the form page will be presented for un-authenticated users, however if a basic auth header is present it will always be used.

setting.label: Use X-Forwarded-For Header
setting.description: If present, use the X-Forwarded-For HTTP header value as the client IP address instead of the source IP address of the HTTP connection. X-Forwarded-For headers are typically added by upstream proxies or firewalls and may be the only reliable way to identify the user's source IP address.

setting.label: Enable Reverse DNS
setting.description: If true, the system's reverse DNS system is used to record the hostname of the client. In some cases this can cause performance issues so it can be disabled if it is not required.

setting.label: Allow Roaming Source Network Address
setting.description: If true, Allow a single HTTP session to be accessed from different source IP addresses. Some load balancing/proxy network infrastructures may require this, but in most cases it should be disabled. Especially since typical sessions are very short, there is generally not a practical reason for a user to access the same session from multiple client addresses.

setting.label: Required HTTP Headers
setting.description:
Required HTTP header name and value pairs. If specified, any HTTP request sent to the server must have these headers to be honored. This feature is useful if you have a security gateway and wish to only allow sessions from the gateway.

The settings must be in "name=value" format.

setting.label: Permitted IP Network Addresses
setting.description:
If specified, only connections originating from the specified IP address ranges will be permitted. If blank (default), any source address is permitted.

Supported range specifications are:

  • Full IPv4 address, e.g. 12.34.56.78
  • Full IPv6 address, e.g. 2001:18e8:3:171:218:8bff:fe2a:56a4
  • Partial IPv4 address, e.g. 12.34 (which matches any IP starting 12.34
  • IPv4 network/netmask, e.g. 18.25.0.0/255.255.0.0
  • IPv4 or IPv6 CIDR slash notation, e.g. 18.25.0.0/16 or 2001:18e8:3:171::/64

setting.label: Page Leave Notice Timeout
setting.description: When a user navigates away from any page, a notice is sent to the server. The next time a page is requested, the timeout is checked to determine if the last page leave time was greater then the timeout, and if so, the user's session will be invalidated. This has the effect of logging out users that navigate away from the application without explicitly logging out.If set to zero, this feature is disabled.

setting.label: Show Detailed Error Messages
setting.description: While useful for administrators, especially during configuration, showing detailed error messages to users may be confusing as well as a security hazard. This setting is ignored until the configuration is closed.

setting.label: SSO Authentication Header Name
setting.description: With this setting enabled, an upstream server can be configured to allow autologin with a only a username, a password is not required. This setting controls the name of the HTTP header. When used, a user will likely be prompted for their password to access certain functionality.

setting.label: Maximum Session Duration
setting.description: Maximum duration of a session (in seconds). Having a maximum session lifetime prevents certain types of long-term session fixation attacks.

setting.label: Prevent HTML Framing
setting.description: When enabled, prevent this application from being displayed inside an IFrame. This is done by setting the X-Frame-Options HTTP Header to DENY on all pages.

setting.label: Redirect Whitelist
setting.description:

  • Each item will be attempted to be matched from the beginning of the requested URL string.

  • If an error occurs when setting a redirect URL, set the debug logs to TRACE and watch the output as the error occurs.
  • Wildcards or case mis-matches are not permitted, the values must match exactly.

setting.label: HTTP Content Security Policy Header
setting.description: Set the HTTP Content-Security-Policy header. This header instructs the browser to limit the locations from which it will load fonts, scripts and css files.

setting.label: System Audit Event Email Alerts
setting.description: Send an email when System Audit events occur to these email addresses.

setting.label: System Audit Event Types
setting.description: Event types to record and act upon.

setting.label: User Audit Event Email Alerts
setting.description: Send an email User Audit events occur to these email addresses.

setting.label: User Audit Event Types
setting.description: Event types to record and act upon.

setting.label: Syslog Audit Server
setting.description:
Syslog audit server. When configured, all audit events will be forwarded to the specified syslog server. The format is <protocol>,<address>,<port>. The value for <protocol> can be either udp or tcp.

ProtocolAddressPortSetting

setting.label: Token Storage Method
setting.description:
Storage method used to save issued tokens.
MethodDescription
LocalDBStores the tokens in the local embedded LocalDB database. Tokens will not be common across multiple application instances.
DBStore the tokens in a configured, remote database. Tokens will work across multiple application instances.
CryptoUse crypto to create and read tokens, they are not stored locally. Tokens will work across multiple application instances if they have the same Security Key. Crypto tokens ignore the length rules and may be too long to use for SMS purposes.
LDAPUse the LDAP directory to store tokens. Tokens will work across multiple application instances. LDAP tokens cannot be used as New User Registration tokens.

setting.label: Token Characters
setting.description: Available characters for the email token.

setting.label: Token Length
setting.description: Length of the email token

setting.label: Token Maximum Lifetime
setting.description: Length of lifetime a token is valid (in seconds). Default is one hour.

setting.label: Token LDAP attribute name
setting.description: When using the LDAP Token Storage Method, this attribute will be used to store and search for tokens.

setting.label: Enable One Time Passwords
setting.description: Set to true to enable the configuration and use of one time password.

setting.label: Force Setup of One Time Passwords
setting.description: If true and one time passwords are enabled, the user will be directed to configure a one time password secret when logging in. The user is forced to configure one time password if they do not have a current valid secret stored.

options.option: Force Setup - but allow user to skip

setting.label: OTP Secret Read Location
setting.description: Location to read the OTP secret from. If an option with multiple values are selected, each location will be read in turn until a stored response is found.

setting.label: OTP Secret Write Location
setting.description: Location to write the OTP secret to. All storage methods will be written to when the user configures their response answers.

setting.label: Token Storage Method
setting.description:
Storage format used to save one time password secrets.
FormatDescription
PWM JSONStore the secret, descriptions and recovery codes in PWM native (json) format.
Base32 secretStore only the TOTP-secret as a base32 encoded string. This format does not support recovery codes or counter based tokens.
OTP URLStore the secret and description as an otpauth:// url, used for generating the QR-code. This format does not support recovery codes.
PAM textStore the secret, description and recovery codes in the text file format, used by the Google Authenticator PAM module.

setting.label: Encrypt OTP secret
setting.description: If enabled, the Security Key is used to encrypt and decrypt token information, to make sure it is not readable as plain text. Multiple application instances must use the same Security Key. If the Security Key is changed, stored OTP passwords will no longer be usable.

setting.label: OTP Secret LDAP Attribute
setting.description: LDAP attribute for storing the OTP secret. This setting is used only when the storage method is set to LDAP.

setting.label: OTP Secret Setup Permission
setting.description: Permission used to determine if a user is a permitted to setup an OTP secret.

setting.label: OTP Secret Identifier
setting.description: User Identifier. Macros are available.

setting.label: OTP Recovery Codes
setting.description: Number of OTP recovery codes to supply to user. Recovery codes can be used one time each to authenticate and are intended for occasions when the user looses access to their OTP device. Set to zero to disable recovery codes. Not all storage formats support recovery codes.

setting.label: Java StdOut Log Level
setting.description: Default Log level for stdout. Most servlet containers will redirect stdout to a log file. For example, tomcat logs stdout output to the tomcat/logs/catalina.out file by default.

setting.label: Log4j Configuration File
setting.description: Location and name of a log4j xml configuration file. If specified, this file will be used to configure the log4j system. If unspecified, the application logging will be configured according to the settings here any and configuration file will be ignored. The location specified by this setting is relative to the WEB-INF directory. An example log4jconfig-sample.xml file is included in the WEB-INF directory.

setting.label: Maximum LocalDB Events
setting.description:
Maximum log events stored in LocalDB. This number of events will be retained in the LocalDB database and use these to display in the admin event log screen.

This setting does not effect the normal log files configured in log4jconfig.xml or tomcat's log file settings.

Approximately 100MB of disk space will be consumed for each 100,000 log events.

setting.label: Maximum Age LocalDB Events
setting.description:
Maximum age of events stored in LocalDB.

This setting does not effect log files configured in log4jconfig.xml or tomcat's log file settings.

Events older than the configured value here will be periodically purged. Value is specified in seconds. Default is 4 weeks (60s * 60m * 24h * 7d * 4w = 2419200). A value of zero will cause events not to be removed due to age.

setting.label: LocalDB Log Level
setting.description: Level at which to log events in the LocalDB. Log events written to the LocalDB can be viewed in the administrator event log viewer.

setting.label: File Log Level
setting.description: Level at which to log events to the local File Log. Log files are written to the servlet's WEB-INF/logs directory.

setting.label: User History Storage Location
setting.description: Data store used for user-specific audit history. If using LDAP, this number should be kept small to avoid an unreasonably lengthy LDAP attribute value size.

options.option: Auto Configure - Database if configured, LDAP otherwise

setting.label: User History LDAP Attribute
setting.description: Attribute used to write a user event attribute in ldap. The user event log attribute will hold an XML document with the users Event history. Leave blank to disable logging event history to ldap.

setting.label: User History Maximum Events
setting.description: Maximum number of events to hold in the event history attribute for a user.

setting.label: Enable LDAP Wire Trace
setting.description:
If true, all ldap traffic will be output to the TRACE logging level.

WARNING: enabling this option may allow user passwords and other sensitive data to be written to the log files.

setting.label: Daily Summary Alerts
setting.description: If true, send an email alert once a day (at 0:00 GMT) summary of the day's statistics and health.

setting.label: LocalDB Audit Events Storage Max Age
setting.description: Maximum age (in seconds) of the local audit event log. Default is 30 days.

setting.label: Enable Setup Responses
setting.description: If enabled, save responses page will be available to users.

setting.label: Force Response Setup
setting.description: If true, the user will be directed to configure challenge/response when logging in. The user is forced to enter responses if they do not have a current valid response stored.

setting.label: Random Questions

setting.label: Required Questions
setting.description: Required Questions for Challenge/Response. The user must supply answers for all of these questions when setting up their responses. Additionally, answers to these questions must be supplied during forgotten password.

setting.label: Minimum Random Required
setting.description: Minimum number of random questions required at time of forgotten password recovery.

setting.label: Minimum Random Challenges Required During Setup
setting.description: The minimum number of random questions the user is required to complete during Response Setup. If this number is higher than the available randoms, or lower than the minimum required, it will be adjusted accordingly. Set to zero to force all available random questions to be configured at time of setup.

setting.label: Show Response Confirmation
setting.description: Show the responses to the user after they configure them. This will give your users an opportunity to read and review their responses before submitting, however it will show the responses on the screen and make them visible to anyone else watching the users screen.

setting.label: Case Insensitive Responses
setting.description: Control the case sensitivity of responses. If marked true, then responses will be deemed correct even if case is wrong. Changing this value does not change existing stored responses -- the case sensitive flag is saved on each user's stored response.

setting.label: Allow Duplicate Responses
setting.description: Control if each response is required to be unique

setting.label: Helpdesk Random Questions
setting.description: The user may be required to supply answers to all or some of these questions when setting up their responses, as controlled by the "Minimum Helpdesk Random Challenges Required During Setup" setting. The questions and answers will be visible to helpdesk users, but are not used for forgotten password recovery.

setting.label: Helpdesk Required Questions
setting.description: The user must supply answers for all of these questions when setting up their responses. The questions and answers will be visible to helpdesk users, but are not used for forgotten password recovery.

setting.label: Minimum Helpdesk Random Challenges Required During Setup
setting.description: The minimum number of helpdesk random questions the user is required to complete during Response Setup. If this number is higher then the available randoms, or lower then the minimum required, it will be adjusted accordingly. Set to zero to force all available randoms to be configured at time of setup.

setting.label: Save Challenge Permission
setting.description: Permission used to determine if a user is a permitted to configure challenges. The user must be returned during this ldap query or else the user will not be permitted to configure challenges.

setting.label: Check Responses Match
setting.description:
If the command servlet is called with the checkResponses command:

/private/CommandServlet?processAction=checkResponses

the user is first checked to see if they match the following LDAP query before the user's password responses is checked. If the user does not match this query, then the user's responses will not be checked, and the user will be redirected to the forward URL.

setting.label: Enforce Minimum Password Lifetime
setting.description: When the user authenticates via ForgottenPassword, should the password minimum lifetime (if set) be enforced? If this setting is true, the user cannot change password if the minimum lifetime hasn't passed. If false, the user is permitted to change their password when authenticated via Forgotten Password even if the minimum lifetime has not changed.

setting.label: Challenge Profile
setting.description:
List of Challenge Profiles. When multiple challenge policies are configured, all profiles except for the default are evaluated in order to check if the Challenge Profile Query Match during user authentication matches the user. If no profiles match, then the Default profile will be used.

Profile names have the following requirements:

  • Start with a letter (a-Z)
  • Contain only letters, numbers and hyphens
  • Length between 2 and 15 characters

setting.label: Enable Forgotten Password
setting.description: If enabled, forgotten password recovery will be available to users.

setting.label: Forgotten Password User Search Form
setting.description: Form fields for activate user module. Each attribute will be required to be entered by the user. Ideally, the user will be required to enter some personal data that is not publicly known.

setting.label: Forgotten Password User Search Filter
setting.description:
LDAP search filter used to search for users during forgotten password recovery.  The LDAP search filter should include each attribute in the Forgotten Password User Search Form. Tokens made of a form item name (such as cn) enclosed with a percent sign %cn% will be replaced with values supplied by the user.

For example, if the Activate User Form included the attributes cn and sn, then this filter may be appropriate:

(&(objectClass=person)(cn=%cn%)(sn=%sn%))

If this setting is left blank, a search filter based on the required items in the Forgotten Password User Search Form will be automatically generated.

setting.label: Response Read Location
setting.description: Location to read the responses from. If an option with multiple values are selected, each location will be read in turn until a stored response is found.

setting.label: Response Write Location
setting.description:
Location to write the responses to. All storage methods will be written to when the user configures their response answers.

WARNING: The LocalDB should never be used to store responses in a production system as there are no methods to make the LocalDB storage redundant, nor are optimal backup methods available for the LocalDB.

setting.label: Response Storage Attribute
setting.description: Attribute to use for response storage when storing to ldap directory. If blank, responses will not be stored in the ldap directory. If configured, responses will be stored to the ldap directory in addition to any other configured storage repositories.

setting.label: Allow Unlock
setting.description: Allow unlock during forgotten password. If true, and if the user's account is locked due to too many invalid login attempts, and the user's password is not expired, then the user will be given a chance to unlock their account instead of resetting their password.

setting.label: Responses Storage Hashing Method
setting.description:
The method of Hashing used to store responses. Storing the responses as plaintext may facilitate synchronization or migration to other systems.

This setting only controls the writing of the responses. Stored responses in other formats can always be read.

setting.label: Required Attributes
setting.description: Required LDAP attributes for forgotten password authentication. These attributes will be required to be supplied by the user as part of the forgotten password autentication process. The LDAP Proxy User will require LDAP compare permission to these attributes.

setting.label: Require Email Token
setting.description: If enabled, a token will be emailed to the user during the forgotten password process. The user will be required to type the email token in order to proceed to recover their password. If this setting is disabled, then at least one other recovery method must be set to true for forgotten password recovery to operate.

setting.label: Delete On Creation Failure
setting.description: If the new user account creation fails for some reason, delete the (potentially partially-created) "broken" account in ldap.

setting.label: LDAP Entry ID Definition
setting.description:
This setting controls the entry id of the newly created LDAP entry. In some directories this is often used as the "username", though many directories separate the concepts and values of entry ID and username.

Values can (and usually do) include macros. In case the first value is already existing in the directory, each successive value is tried until a free value is found. Though the user is not yet created when the macros are evaluated, LDAP macros will use the data provided on the new user form. Other macros may not be useful as there no data yet available on the user.

If blank, the username must be present in the form, defined as the LDAP naming attribute value.

setting.label: Enable New User SMS Verification
setting.description: If true, an SMS will be sent to the new user's mobile phone number before the account is created. The NewUser must verify receipt of the SMS before the account will be created.

setting.description: User to use as template for password policy. The user specified here will be used as a 'template' for the new user password policy. If the value is TESTUSER, the configured test user's password policy will be used.

During a new user creation, the user will be delayed for at least this amount of time before forwarding the user to the next activity.

setting.label: Activate User Agreement Message
setting.description: Message to display to user before being allowed to activate their account. If blank, the activate user agreement page will not be displayed to the user. This message may include HTML tags.

setting.description: Form fields for activate user module. Each attribute will be required to be entered by the user. Ideally, the user will be required to enter some personal data that is not publicly known.

setting.label: Activation Search Filter

LDAP search filter used to search for users during user activation.  The LDAP search filter should include each attribute in the Activate User Form. Tokens made of a form item name (such as cn) enclosed with a percent sign %cn% will be replaced with values supplied by the user.

For example, if the Activate User Form included the attributes cn and sn, then this filter may be appropriate:

(&(objectClass=person)(cn=%cn%)(sn=%sn%))

Any attributes that are listed in the form but are not used in the search filter will tested by performing an LDAP compare operation with the user supplied value.

If this setting is left blank, a search filter based on the required items in the Activate User Search Form will be automatically generated.

setting.label: Activation Permission
setting.description: Only allow users who match this query to be activated. Generally, you will only allow users who have never been authenticated and are not disabled to activate. The default example uses the last login time attribute(s) on the user object to determine if the user has never logged in. It is the responsibility of the administrator to ensure this activation feature works correctly. Misconfiguration could potentially result in unintended activations being able to take place.

setting.label: Post-Activation Actions (After Password Change)

setting.label: LDAP Photo HTML Style Attribute

setting.label: Enable NMAS Extensions
setting.description:
When connecting to a NetIQ eDirectory LDAP directory, this parameter will control if NMAS extensions will be used when connecting to the ldap directory. Enabling nmas results in:
  • better error messages when using universal password policies
  • better error handling during certain change password scenarios
Unless you are using an older version of eDirectory (pre 8.8 or before), it is generally best to set this to true.

All NMAS operations require an SSL connection to the directory.

setting.label: Save NMAS Responses
setting.description: If true, user responses will be saved to the NMAS response storage container on the user. This storage is in addition to any other configured response storage methods.

setting.label: Enable NMAS Responses for Forgotten Password
setting.description: If true, NMAS stored responses will be used for forgotten password recovery. All other configured storage methods will be tried before the NMAS stored responses will be evaluated.

setting.label: Read User Passwords
setting.description: If true, the user's password will be read from eDirectory before changing it. This prevents an extra password change from being set to a temporary random password during forgotten password sequence. If the proxy user does not have rights to read the password, then a temporary random password will be generated for the user anyway.

setting.label: Read eDirectory Challenge Sets
setting.description: If true, the challenge set configuration from eDirectory Universal Password policy will be read and applied to users. If an eDirectory challenge set is applied to the user, that policy will be used, otherwise the policy that is a part of this configuration will be used. To require only NMAS configured challenge sets, be sure to blank out the required and forgotten questions as part of this configuration, or else those will be used in cases where no eDirectory policy.

setting.label: UserApp Password SOAP Service URL
setting.description:
If supplied, this setting will change the behavior of the forgotten password function. Instead of using the normal mechanism to read the responses stored in ldap, the NetIQ UserApp forgotten password web service will be used to discover the user's stored questions and test the user's responses. If the forgotten password web service indicates success, then the user will be forwared to the change password screen which operates through LDAP. The web services's "processChgPwd" method will not be used and instead the user's new password will be set via ldap.

Example: https://10.1.1.1:8443/IDM/pwdmgt/service

Note: A secure (https) URL should be used for security reasons. You may need to import the HTTPS certificate into the java keystore.
Note: The UserApp Password SOAP service only exists in NetIQ UserApp v3.7 or greater.

Use Proxy When Password Forgotten
setting.description: If true, when the user's password is forgotten, the system will use the ldap proxy account for ldap work. This is because an ldap connection is not possible to AD without the user's password. When authenticated in this condition, the user will be forced to change password immediately.

setting.label: Allow Authentication When "Must Change Password On Next Login" Is Set
setting.description: Active Directory will fail an ldap login attempt when the user's "must change password on next login" flag is set. If this option is enabled, the system will allow login even though the ldap bind has failed. The user will only be able to set a new password when this condition occurs. No other functions will be available until the password has been set (and this flag is cleared).

setting.label: Allow Authentication When Password Expired
setting.description: Active Directory will fail an ldap login attempt when the current date is after the user's password expiration date. If this option is enabled, the system will allow login even though the ldap bind has failed. The user will only be able to set a new password when this condition occurs. No other functions will be available until the password has been set (and this flag is cleared).

setting.label: Enforce Password Policy During Forgotten Password
setting.description: Enforce password policy during forgotten password when Use Proxy When Password Forgotten is also set to true. This setting requires that the AD servers be at Windows 2008 Server R2 SP1 or later. More specifically, it requires that the AD servers support the LDAP_SERVER_POLICY_HINTS_OID (1.2.840.113556.1.4.2066) LDAP modification control.

setting.label: Allow Manipulation of PasswordAllowChangeTime
setting.description: If enabled, during the forgotten password recovery sequence, allow manipulation of the allowPasswordChangeTime attribute. This allows forgotten password functionality with expected behavior when a policy of minimum time between password changes is enforced.

setting.label: Allow Authentication When "Require Password Change at First Login and After Reset" Is Set
setting.description: Oracle Directory Server will normally fail an ldap login attempt when the user's pwdReset attribute is set due to an administrator password set. If this option is enabled, the system will allow login even though the ldap bind has failed. The user will only be able to set a new password when this condition occurs. No other functions will be available until the password has been set (and this flag is cleared).

Value is specified in seconds.

setting.label: Minimum Cache Age

For example, setting this value to one day (86400) would mean that a given cached report record would only be read once every day, regardless of how often the report is run. This also means that the average record in the report would be approximately one day out of date.

Value is specified in seconds.

A value of zero will result in the report process running as quickly as possible but user performance may suffer.
